p: Gunjegaonkar and Shanmugarajan [ 110] note that the antioxidant and antimicrobial properties of methyl jasmonate are the basis for its use as a food preservative and that its anti-inflammatory properties provide a rationale for clinical applications. The above-mentioned results with T. vaginalis indicate this could include the treatment of trichomoniasis. Potentially other plant stress hormones and bioactive compounds, including auxins, gibberellins, cytokinins, abscisic acid, salicylic acid, brassinosteroids, and strigolactones that are synthesized within specialized plant cells, could exhibit anti-trichomonad properties.
